dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final image of the Civil War graveyard is now project on a classroom screen. COLLEGE KIDS sit at their desks, glassy eyed and open mouthed. PROFESSOR ACKERMAN walks among them; bearded, bespectacled and bewitched by his manic reverie.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: More American citizens, 618,002 to be exact, died in our own Civil War than in both of the so-called... (makes quotes with his fingers) ..."World Wars" combined. In the front row, a sexy AFRICAN AMERICAN COED mimics Ackerman's hand gesture. Beside her sits ANDERSON LEE, th ultimate golden boy: charming, muscular body, sensitive eyes... Basically, the model student, were he not fixated on the girl's uncovered thigh, a predicament which brings th shapely nymphet much amusement.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Now when we consider how the North ended the Civil War with General Sherman's vindictive march through Georgia, his Union troops raping, looting, hell, annihilating dozens of small towns swept away in the carnage... Inexplicably, this information appears to turn on the Coe which, of course turns on Anderson... And the Professor.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: ».-well, we can truly understand the rage, the betrayal the South felt towards the North, and, to some degrees, still feels today. Ackerman now notices an empty fast food box on Anderson's desk.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Speaking of carnage... Is that a CarnoBurger you got there, Anderson? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Um... yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Did you know the meat in that six ounce patty most likely came from as many as 1000 different cows? Two rows back sits CORY JONES, the closest thing to an intellectual in the Northern U fraternity. Half asleep, Cory slumps at his desk, unaware of the raging hard-on poking through his Bilabongs. NELSON ELLIOT, however, does notice. An uncompromising, unrelenting (and uncoordinated) court jester, Nelson dump his Pepsi Blue on Cory's crotch, jolting him from his daz

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Mommy!!!! The entire class turns to stare at Cory. But not Ackerman He's still on his roll...

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: The need to produce the cheapest product possible commands that the fast food chains literally own the... (makes quotes with his fingers "Smiley Meal" from its very birth. Anderson makes the quote gesture to the teasing Coed who once again giggles. Winks.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Thus your CarnoBurger is born a cow, and your ChickNugget, a beakless, large breasted mute.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sounds like your sister, Corndog!

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Nelson... Lick my rim. The bell RINGS. Books are gathered. Hi-fives exchanged. These kids are the fuck outta there.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Fine. Good. Go! But the next time you all pig out, be aware... You are what you eat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our trio walks along the campus, inhaling the fresh air. Nelson carries a boogie board.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Oh, Northern-U, venerated dwelling place of those who got wait listed at real colleges, we bid thee adieu for ten long days...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Of killer surf...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: And genetically altered, ice cold brew...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: And fine ass... An obscenely CURVACEOUS COED walks by, brushing the guys aside with obvious distaste.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ahem, mighty, fine ass... She gives Nelson the finger as she disappears.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That is pure sexual harassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the lot. Top down, Anderson's convertible muscle car sits at the end, parked perpendicularly across two spots. Several parking tickets grace the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: These tickets are three weeks old.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Then they're probably no good. Cory grabs the tickets and puts them on a late model Volv in the adjacent spot. Nelson begins tearing off his cloth ranting like the madman that he is.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Bond with the boys! Stick it in the puss! Bond with the boys... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down to his "Beach Fun" swim trunks, Nelson hops round th lot. Eternally immune, Anderson and Cory focus on clearin out the many beer bottles and junk food wrappers which clutter the otherwise spotless convertible.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You know, dude, as excited as I am that now is now, you know, Spring Break, time to get savaged by some slop-drunk "Babes Gone Wild" hotties, I’m also kinda realizing that the deal of a major life experience like this is the "looking forward to", as opposed to the actual "doing of"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks blankly at Cory.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Corndog, have you been jacking off with your mother’s hand créme again?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Maybe just a little... Professor Ackerman arrives, arms full of books for the spring break “read”. He pauses by the Volvo (which is, of course, his), and removes the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Lee, on being assigned a spot in the faculty lot. Ackerman studies Anderson's horrid parking job. Amused.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Is this what you call parking... (makes quotes with his fingers -.."outside the box"?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Hey, I like that! Ackerman hands Anderson the clump of tickets.

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Too bad the Meter Maid didn't. Nelson hops over, boogie board in tow.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yo, Professor Ackerman! I was just... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: I take it this will not be a trip devoted to what Joseph Campbell refers to as the “Journey Within’?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, we plan to journey within, sir. Just not inside a book. The African American Coed from class enters the lot. Anderson poses and smiles... as the Coed walks right past him to Ackerman, seductively adding her books to his pile

dialogues.speaker: ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll excuse me, boys, I have my own noble quest to take care of. See you next Wednesday. Ackerman loads the girl into his car. The guys can only stare in awe.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: It's good to be the Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat later... The convertible backs out of the lot. Anderson sits behin the wheel, Cory rides shotgun. The half naked Nelson stan on the back seat, beach ball in hand, guiding Anderson pa their fellow STUDENTS who dart out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Left... Left... Right... Right... Bingo! Now point this fucking thing south, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car hurls away from the school. Let the road trip beg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top down, the guys take in the smog filled freeway.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (offscreen/singing) Waste me! Lay my body bare! Waste me! Push my soul to care!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson strums an acoustic guitar in the back seat, warbli along to the RADIO. Poorly.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Hey, Nelson. Who sings this again?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: That would be my favorite new band, Waste.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Right. So keep it that way.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck you, Corndog!

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That's witty.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Enough, girls! Time for today's "Sucks to be You".

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Man...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Bring it, baby.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Okay, Cory, since you're so up for it. You will either, A, star in a new reality show, which you discover too late is a gay version of "Survivor"...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Brutal!

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: ...and your one pair of tightie whities has a huge hole in the ass, an incredible turn-on for the all male cast, or...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Ouch!!!

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: ...-B, go down on Chelsea Clinton in front of your entire family, S.C.S. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Stone cold sober, bro. Cory winces. Contemplates the implications of both.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Can't I just kill myself?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You know the rules! Don't choose one, you get both. Rammed on Pleasure Island while eating out Chelsea!

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (after much consideration) Butt Pirates, come and get it!

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: That was time well spent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car continues South. Odd billboards dot the landscape "The Blue and Grey Motel". "Stonewall's Civil War Funpark "Sambo's Flapjacks - Where Johnny Comes Marching Home". Finally, there's a signpost up ahead. "Welcome to Georgia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much sun left. The guys exit the car and stretch. Loo around. Nelson pumps the gas.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Man, I am so sick of driving thru hick towns on life support that have morphed into Civil War tourist attractions! The whole point was getting away from history class.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Chill, dude. I figure if we drive all night, we'll be quaffing brews by four and boffing babes by five! A MAN in torn overalls walks by and spits at the guys' fe

dialogues.speaker: OVERALL MAN
dialogues.text: And pushing up daises by midnight... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, a BANJO begins to play. On the front porch of the station, a YOUNG BOY strums a familiar tune. He smile his three good teeth showing. Encouraged, Nelson grabs hi guitar from the convertible and begins strumming along. Anderson and Cory join in, CLAPPING and WHISTLING.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Go, banjo boy, go! SCREECH! A silver Mustang convertible, top down, skids in the station. One lucky dude sits behind the wheel, drivin with two amazing babes. By the way they giggle and grope each other, it's immediately clear there is some kind of “wild thing” between the three.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Holy... The passenger door opens. KAT, a dark-haired, tattooed, belt-and-buckled vixen kicks her way out and heads for th mini-market.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: ...shit. Then it gets worse as a blonde knockout hops from the bac and stretches. This is JOEY, a self-contained packet of both sugar and spice.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, God, bro. She's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (locking eyes with Joey She's not your type, dude. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, man. I think Anderson just pissed on your hydrant. Undeterred, Cory walks up to the car. RICKY, the driver, nods. He looks like he could be one of the Backstreet Boy if one of them ever quit to sing lead for the Sex Pistols

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What's up, dude?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Just, you know, a little road trip with the ladies. Name's Ricky. Cory ignores. Checks out Joey. She smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Where you guys heading?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, ah... I got a buddy in Daytona with a beach house. On the beach.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Really. A beach house on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: And in Daytona, no less. Must be fate, huh, Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Must be. Cuz, we're heading there manana. Right, Kitty Kat? Kat's arrived with chips and sodas. She looks Cory over.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: After tonight, of course, when we violate yet another motel room. And each other. Kat winks. Growls. Cory swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Cool. Well, ah... We should all hook up when you guys hit town.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Good idea. We should all hook up.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You got a number, hon?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure... Um, you wouldn't happen to have a pen... or paper?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (eyes still fixed on Anderson) Who needs paper? Joey lifts her shirt to expose an incredible pierced bell Jaws drop. Ricky laughs as he and Kat get back in the car

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: He's done. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anderson makes his move, marker in hand, brushing past Cory. Joey smiles. Now THIS is more like it. Anderson kneels down, coolly writes his number on her amazing abs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me your name.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (flustered) Corndog. I mean... Cory. Wasn't talking to him. Joey stares down at Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Whenever you're finished... He is, but it's just so great down there.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: ...Anderson. He finally stands. Joey gets into the car with the others

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: What about your name?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you... if I call.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Later, Corndog. Ricky guns the engine. The Mustang takes off.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Was that a score? I can't really say.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She'll call... She wants the house. Anderson smirks, tosses Nelson the keys. Notes Overall Ma leering, munching on a shoefly scraped off the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: We're in deliverance country now, Nelson, so unless you're into squealing like Porky Pig's love bitch, none of your short cuts! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You know, you guys have no faith. The three pile into the convertible and head off, coating Banjo Boy with dust as he continues his tune undaunted. Overall Man chews. Cackles.

dialogues.speaker: OVERALL MAN
dialogues.text: ...and pushing up daisies by midnight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full moon looms in the midnight sky, lording over all

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANDERSON'S CONVERTIBLE, (DRIVING)
dialogues.text: Nelson tries to keep his eyes open. The other guys are ou cold. He fumbles with the RADIO. Nothing but Southern preachers and bad country music. A weird song about how "The South is Gonna Rise Again".

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, Corndog? What's "quaffing"? No response. His eyelids lower.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Is that Latin or something? KAPOW!! Tire blowout! The car veers left. Right. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Desolate. Nelson kneels before the shredded tire.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Uh, fellas. A little help here. From inside the convertible, Anderson and Cory stir, kicking over their empty beer bottles. The only sound to heard... other than the mournful HOWLING OF WILD COYOTES! Flustered, Nelson begins to rock the car back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yoo hoo! Oh, boys!!!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nelson stops shaking the car. SILENCE. Then FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb your sorry ass, Corndog, but I could really use... Nelson looks up from his kneeling position. Overall Man stands directly above, his frothing mouth fixed in a twis grin! His hands clutch the banjo, held high like a club.

dialogues.speaker: OVERALL MAN
dialogues.text: It's midnight! THWACK! Overall Man brings the banjo down hard, cracking Nelson's head against the hubcap. Nelson crumples back on the road, brains spilling from his shattered skull...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANDERSON'S CONVERTIBLE, (DRIVING)
dialogues.text: Nelson wakes with a start from what has been his NIGHTMAR Up ahead, a flaming torch burns brightly, illuminating a wooden sign smack dab in the middle of the road. He slams on the brakes, nearly hitting this crudely painted DETOUR SIGN. A large arrow points to a dirt clearing on the righ Nelson sits at the wheel. Catches his breath. The guys ha not even stirred. With little choice, Nelson follows the sign's directions, turning off the freeway onto the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson navigates the convertible along the very narrow, very dark dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Think we should turn around? He looks at his two buddies. Dead drunk.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ANDERSON'S CONVERTIBLE, (DRIVING)
dialogues.text: Nelson drives a few more yards. Wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Way to stay up with me, guys. Too tired to continue, Nelson pulls over, done for the ni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convertible rests on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are fast asleep. Anderson is the first to wake. shoves Nelson, who rouses with a FART.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Wassup...?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Why do I have a feeling we're not on the highway anymore? From behind, Cory stirs, oblivious to the morning wood saying "hello" through his baggy shorts.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Don't even tell me you took one of your friggin' short cuts!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Chill out, Pinocchio. There was a detour sign pointing this way, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Detour sign?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I tried to wake your ass. It's your fault, too. Kind of...

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: My fault?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, your fault! If you hadn't said shit about being Porky Pig's love bitch, I would'a never had this frigging nightmare...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Let me get this. You had a bad dream, and that's why we're here?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yeah. No... It was the detour sign! Look, I got killed in that dream. That is not supposed to happen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: I only drove a couple miles, anyway. Anderson spots something in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Looks like there's a town up ahead. Let's grab some chow and figure out where the hell we are.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY ROAD- DAY
dialogues.text: The convertible drives down the road, passing a road sign bearing the legend "You are now entering Pleasant Valley"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a county fair is in progress. Hundreds of SOUTHERNERS of all ages fill the area; eating pie, roasti corn and dancing square. Confederate flags abound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top down, the convertible rolls under a banner proclaimin "Pleasant Valley. Population 2001".

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Must be a holiday.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Is today Passover or something?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: You truly are a moron, Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flanked by two STROLLING MINSTRELS, an official-looking, goateed gentleman walks over to the car. A black patch emblazoned with the confederate flag covers his left eye. MAYOR GEORGE W. BUCKMAN.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Welcome to Pleasant Valley! The guys take in the scene, unsure what to think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Don't be a wet ding dong, fellas! Buckman's the name. Mayor's my game! Now why don't y'all give us a Howdy Doo? Buckman holds out his hand, hospitable and friendly-like. The guys shrug. Step out of the car. Why not...

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Anderson Lee. Nice to meet you, sir. My two buds here go by... Eager townsfolk swarm the trio, shaking hands, patting ba

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Anderson Lee! What a beautiful surname! Ya ain't from the south, are ya?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (slips into Southern accent) Born and bred, sir. Lived in South Carolina till Freshman year...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: But ya moved to the other side, I see! Well, ya might be savable yet. Ya see, you and your compatriots have arrived just in time to be this year's Guests of Honor! An OVATION greets the news.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: And lookie here, looks like we've got more honored guests fresh on the way! The silver Mustang, top down, pulls into town. Ricky, Joe and Kat trade looks with our threesome, equally confused.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Is this some hillbilly reality show type thing?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Friends, for the next two days it's gonna be one big party! Nothing but dancing, games, a good old fashioned barrel roll... and best of all, our world famous barbecue! EXPLOSION of cheering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (low, to his buds) I say we get the hell out of Dodge. These people are freaks.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Well that sure is freaky in all the right places! Cory points out a young girl sucking a lollipop. Pure Southern jailbait in tank top and cutoffs, she stands behind a wooden stall: The "John Wilkes Kissing Booth". Prancing over, she removes her lolli and smiles... revealing the worse set of choppers ever seen by man!

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: Hey, studs! Jailbait, er, PEACHES, leans on the hood, flashing her perky cleavage. Cory is hooked, buckteeth and all.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: You're kinda cute.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Um, hi.....

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Easy, Corndog. Fourteen'll get you twenty.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: In what? Dental prison? Mayor Buckman puts his arm around Peaches.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Like I said, boys, all ya needs gonna be met. Ain't that right, Peaches?! The Mustang gang walks over to the boys. Joey picks out Anderson with her deadly smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm game for anything.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: We've done crazier.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (staring at Joey) We'll stay if you guys stay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey grins. Nods affirmative. The Mayor steps in.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Then it's settled! Let's show our guests some Southern hospitality! From the distance, a ROAR is heard. Everyone looks toward an approaching plume of DUST. It's a MOTORCYCLE, heading for town. All eyes upon them, the bike's leather clad riders come to a stop, then slowly remove their helmets. The driver, MALCOLM, is black. LEAH, his partner, is Asia The townsfolk GASP.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What the hell kinda detour is this? Stunned silence. Finally, Mayor Buckman regains composure

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Judas priest! If we ain't got us two more Yanks for the Festival! And a Negra and a Chinaman to boot!

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Easy with the ethnic slander, Cracker Joe! Leah shakes loose her long, flowing black hair.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: And that's Chinawoman.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: And what a woman! Well don't just stand around folks! We got rooms at Granny's fixing to wait for you! The silence turns to CHEERING as the Minstrels begin to play. The townsfolk envelop the guests, carrying them to the hotel like conquering heroes. Everyone, Malcolm and Leah included, has little choice but to go with the flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eight guests enter an old fashioned, cozy hotel. Things are looking up. Counters overflow with tasty Southern treats; fried chicken, peach cobbler, watermelon A black, BUG-EYED BUSBOY offers Malcolm a big, juicy slic

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Amos. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Two absolutely gorgeous girls, HESTER and GLENDORA, walk over to Anderson, Nelson and Cory. They could be twins.

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: I'm Hester, and this is Glendora.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Corndog. The girls giggle.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I mean Cory. Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: Granny Boone says we're 'sposed to show you to your rooms, Corncob!

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Make sure you show "Corncob" the bed. The girls giggle again.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: They actually think you're funny.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Guess you just have to be a Southern intellectual to get my humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange sign adorns the rickety old drinkin' place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayor Buckman paces behind the bar. RUFUS and LESTER, his hillbilly sons, sit dutifully before him, both young and hunky, both dumb as door nails. Besides Lester lies JEZEBEL, his large, loyal, shabby sheep.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Now boys, I don't know how in the hell you let those two devils in...

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: It was Lester's fault, daddy. He done forgot to take down the Detour sign after that fine automobile with them titty bitties went by! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ on a cracker!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: Little China Doll, ain't she sweet? I'd reckon she'd make a real tasty treat! Now dance ‘er on up to the Podium of Honor! And let's bestow the honor upon ‘er! Peaches and the Milk Maiden dance over and lead Leah and Ricky to the porch. The two stand side by side, clapping time to the music. Feeling daring, Ricky breaks into an impromptu Backstreet Boys routine.

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: Now the time has come to do what's right!

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: ‘Cuz we've only begun to renew the fight!

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Fight!

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: To avenge a horror that occurred in this place... The music stops. Granny Boone stares right at Leah. Speak

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: .»..it's your maker, now, bitch, you'll have to face! Granny Boone tugs hard on the cord. The five ton bell dro from above, flattening Leah like a gory pancake. Entrails spray everywhere. With deft panache, the girls open their parasols to block the shower.

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: Damn, that China Woman had a lot of guts!

dialogues.speaker: MILK MAIDEN
dialogues.text: And she danced real pretty too! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ricky stares at Leah's arms and legs which protrude from the boulder like the "Wicked Witch of the East". Freaked beyond belief, he takes off. The girls pursue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ricky rounds the barn right into the arms of Rufus.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Gotcha!

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: What the fuck...?!

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: We just fixin' to make us one'a them Shis-kee-Bobs, loverboy! Rufus drags Ricky over to a barbecue pit, where the townsfolk and an open-hearth FIRE roar. Buckman walks ove

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: I see the Festival's in full swing! Enjoying yourselves, ladies? Granny Boone and the girls CLAP and CHEER! Rufus slams Ricky spread eagle onto a wooden picnic table.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: And how 'bout our honored guest? He havin' so much fun he just can't stand it? Ricky can't answer. He's fixated on what's going on behin him. The Barbecuties have lined up, holding a long, sharp gleaming steel POLE.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: I see our Barbecuties got the skewerin' pole all ready! Ricky's eyes go wide as Rufus holds him down. The pole is now lined up with his rear end.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Ramming speed! The girls thrust the pole forward. Ricky SCREAMS as the tip of the skewer rips through his open mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: Lookee lou! It's Rick on a stick! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Huge CELEBRATION. Buckman heads off, trailed by his sons.

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: I swear I didn't enjoy myself none with that fella, Pappy!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You a liar. You always volunteer for sissy detail when it presents itself!

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Do not!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Do so!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Will you boys please shut your traps! It is then Buckman takes note of Jezebel, who proudly sports a confederate flag sweater.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell you do to that mutton chop now?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Why, I done knit Jezebel a sweater!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Done knit Jezebel a sweater? Jezebel is a goddamned sweater, you moron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud, raucous southern saloon. Anderson, Cory and Malcolm sit at the back table. They look tired, but troopers that they are, still manage to work the mugs in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: It was so wrong, bro, like Jerry Springer, southern style. They couldn't get enough of me. What was I gonna do? Deny them? Hog myself? And that's not the coolest part. Cory leans in, to keep the next bit private.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Check this out. They're cousins. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Corndog, you are the man! Malcolm slams down a mug.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don't care what you guys say, this place is fucked up. You don't get something for nothing. I'm gonna find Leah, and I'm outta here.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: This place isn't so bad. From behind them, Joey enters. Slams her mug on the table

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Does any of this even remotely resemble any place you've been to? I mean, have you guys ever been anywhere that didn't have phones or electricity? Joey sits down next to Anderson. All business.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I was just back at my room. My pager and cell are fucking gone. Kat's nowhere to be found. That's not like her. She would never just disappear. And where the hell is your good old buddy, Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (to Anderson) You know, bro, it's really not like Nelson to vanish with all this beer around. Even if he was gakking that Kat chick, you know he'd still launch her at some point for free brew.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You went off with Leah. Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Drinking corn liquor and guest starring on Hee Haw. Look, bottom line, this is a bunch of bullshit. We can get free booze in Daytona. I'm tired of being the Guest of Honor. Silence as it all sinks in. And then... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: She's right. I'm going after Leah. g Malcolm rises to leave. Anderson touches his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Look. We need to work together on this. As a team. Let's split up. Find Kat and Nelson. Find our rides. And I say we watch each other's back. We're in this together, right? He looks around the table. At Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You got it, bro. We're tight till we all hit the road.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Good. I'll check out the ride situation. Malcolm, you find Leah. (to Cory and Joey) You guys head back to the rooms and get whatever stuff they haven't ripped off. (big fake smile) Now everybody act like this is all great. We love it. Don't let on we're gonna bail. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Now we're talking. They get up to leave. Buckman, Harper, Rufus and Lester block their way. The Mayor has his arm around Granny.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: You folks weren't inclining to leave town now, were ya?

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want us thinkin' you're insultin' our heritage, would you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Of course not. We're thrilled to be part of your thing here. So if you'll... Buckman pulls back his coat. Brandishes a sharp, silver broadsword from the scabbard at his side.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Harper pulls out his spiked gapping shoe and begins cleaning his nails with it.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: I'll only say this once. This is the biggest day of the year for the people of Pleasant Valley. You could say it's sacred. So y'all don't want to go upsetting my kinfolk. Trust me on that.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: You see, we don't take too kindly to rejection. Been known to react harshly to them that crosses us. Anderson notices that Harper has gouged his fingertips. Blood seeps through the nails. Harper merely smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (accent slightly more southern) I guess you're right, Mayor. We shouldn't be so fast to up and leave... this fine Festival. Long wait. Is Buckman buying the bullshit? Of course he i He puts away his sword.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Good. Now y'all best git goin'. Wouldn't want to miss the Barbecue. Anderson nods. Leads the group out the door, all eyes upo them, like a closely watched funeral procession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, Cory, Joey and Malcolm exit the bar onto the street which is now filled with TOWNSFOLK. Each "Guest of Honor" can feel the people's stares, and for the first time, sense the rot behind the colorful facade. Creepy... Cory sidles up to Anderson as they pass a skinny, hairles teen, ONION JOE, who stands before a scorched confederate flag. Next to him is the BUTCHER, in bloodied apron.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What do you think happened to Nelson?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Nothing happened to him. There's a simple explanation for all of this. Don't worry, buddy.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buckman stands on a chair, addressing the enraptured crow

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Folks, I'd like to propose a toast. To us, survivors, in a spiritual sense, of the worst atrocity of all times, the War Between The States! Buckman raises his mug. The crowd follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey and Malcolm cross paths with the fierce REVEREND JON and his young, twin acolytes, OPIE and LAURA LEE.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I always said the South hasn't changed a damn. Leah would always get mad at me when I'd say that...

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Kat and Ricky and me... We've done some wild things... Nothing beats this. Jonas clutches his bible, gazing in judgment, as his long black beard blows in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Yeah. All for a free meal. Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd has tears in their eyes as they clink glasses, holding on to Buckman's every word.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: I know you fine folks of Pleasant Valley have suffered more than seems possible. But one day, we will find rest. We will be avenged. Orgasmic APPLAUSE and approval.  62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLACKSMITH regards Anderson and Cory as they now pass him by. His eyes are solid white. Milky. Blank.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Dude... What do you think this Festival is really all about?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: No clue. But in the 'Sucks to be You' department, we either, A, stick around and find out or, B, locate Nelson and jet. To Cory's right, an overgrown manchild, GIBLET, sits nake in a water trough. His bearded chaperone, AUNT SUZY Q, rests quietly on a stool, smoking a corn cob pipe.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Easiest one yet, bro. We're history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Strolling Minstrels strum "Battle Hymn of the Republi as Buckman winds up his oratory.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: And I tell you now, each and every one of you fine, searching souls, as God is my witness, I swear we won't never go hungry again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson and Cory fall in line Joey and Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Okay, kids. One hour. We'll regroup at the hotel. Malcolm walks ahead of the group, speaking loud, purposefully, for all the Townsfolk to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, all right, then! See y'all at the BBQ. Don't be late! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anderson embraces Joey, trying to look casual. Kinda toug to do when the local undertaker, COFFIN HARRY, is loudly hammering nails into pine boxes on his front porch.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Like he said, babe. Don't be late. I still gotta give you my e-mail address...

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You bet... They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Come on, Cory. Let's go. Cory low-fives Anderson, then walks off with Joey. Anders lingers, watching them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm sneaks around the back yard of a wooden cottage. Looking for a clue. Looking for Leah. He passes TWO YOUNG BOYS who play in the yard, hovering over a strange contraption made of Lincoln Logs. It looks like a mini-ski slope down which they roll a mini-beer barrel. Inside the barrel, a frightened MOUSE struggles t keep its balance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory and Joey hide behind the weeping willow and scope ou the hotel. They watch as Rufus loads their stuff, in fact all of the "Guest of Honor's" belongings, onto a wagon. They look at each other, for the first time really afraid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalking about like a ninja, Anderson approaches the barn doors and gives them a tug. Locked. Looking around, he spots a pile of hay bails. He climbs on top, then pulls himself up onto the barn roof. The rubber soles of his shoes do not make for good traction, and it's all he can to maintain his grip. That's a real shame, because down below Hester and Glendora are making their way around the barn, absorbed in song. And they've both got shotguns!!!!!  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm slowly edges around the cottage... walking right into the fucking Strolling Minstrels who sit on the front porch! The musicians waste no time serenading with yet another of their lame ditties.

dialogues.speaker: STROLLING MINSTREL A
dialogues.text: There are lessons in this world. Some are easy, some are hard...

dialogues.speaker: STROLLING MINSTREL B
dialogues.text: To swallow, that is...

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not this shit again. Malcolm brushes them off in disgust and walks down the di road. But the duo gets up. Follows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson hangs on to the roof for dear life as Hester and Glendora chatterbox below.

dialogues.speaker: HESTER/GLENDORA
dialogues.text: Nothing is so sweet when you're munching on the meat of a Yankee who's doodle is so dandy...

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: You think Mayor Buckman would mind much if we kept that Anderson boy to ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, cousin. I'd rather kill him than fuck him any day! Anderson loses his hold and slides down the roof. He catches himself just before falling to the ground. Whew!

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: Shhh! Ya' hear somethin'? The girls check out the barn, walking directly beneath Anderson. He holds on to the edge of the roo, the jagged wood cutting into his flesh....

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: Probably just a rooster.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm walks down the lane, trailed by the Strolling Minstrels. They sing as they stalk.

dialogues.speaker: STROLLING MINSTRELS
dialogues.text: There was once a young lassie, Slant-eyed and kind of sassy... He walks faster. They walk faster.

dialogues.speaker: STROLLING MINSTRELS
dialogues.text: She had airs and conceit, Till Granny she did meet. Malcolm stops. Turns to face the Hillbilly Duo.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Any of you shit-for-brains know where my lady is, you better tell me now!

dialogues.speaker: STROLLING MINSTRELS
dialogues.text: The boy wants his bitch. Yeah, the boy wants his bitch. Sad, sad thing, a boy without his bitch. And then they stop. Smile. Point. Malcolm turns to see th familiar leather clad-form of Leah up ahead on the path. Her long, black hair blows in the breeze as she playfully dodges into the thicket, GIGGLING. Malcolm grins. Relieve

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Talk about a sight for sore eyes! He chases after her up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stream of Anderson's BLOOD slowly trickles down the roo Hester and Glendora chat below...

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: That reminds me of a joke Granny told me. What's the difference between a rooster and Ellie May?

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: Well I'm sure I don't know, cousin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The rivulet of red gets closer to the edge. Anderson is sweating quite profusely. Of all the times for jokes!

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: A rooster says "Cock a doodle do" and Ellie May says "Any cock will do"! Anderson winces. A droplet of blood spills downward, head directly for them...

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: That's disgustin'! Hester takes Glendora by the hand and pulls her away. The blood splatters on the ground, barely missing them both!

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: Now enough of your chatterbox. We've got a festivation to attend. WHEW! Anderson breaths relief. Renews his efforts to make his way up the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leah runs out of a thicket into a wide open field. In the middle is a large wooden platform, like a watchtower, nea twenty feet tall. A wooden sliding board leads down from top to a giant bulls-eye painted on the stone landing bel Leah GIGGLES, tosses her hair. Heads up the watchtower la

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: C'mon, baby. No more clowning around! Malcolm follows, hand over foot. Leah reaches the top. A large beer barrel rests on a slab. The barrel is open at both ends. She crawls inside.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Okay, we both know Daddy likes games. But you had me worried. Where the hell you been, anyway? More GIRLISH GIGGLES from the barrel. Going along with th game, Malcolm walks over to the keg and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Give me a wet one, sugar muff. Malcolm closes his eyes, puckers up. Nothing. What? No ki He opens his eyes... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ...coming face to face with the twisted grimace of Lester his face smeared with lipstick and rouge!!! Leah's bloody scalp rests atop his head. He wears her leather duds.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What the fuck...? From inside the barrel, Lester grabs Malcolm's wrists and yanks him through. Rufus pops out a trapdoor from below, joining Lester as he wrestles with Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you people? Despite his kicks of protest, Lester and Rufus manage to Malcolm, tying his hands behind his back. They then posit him so that his head and feet extend from either end of t keg. From his new perspective, Malcolm can now see that Mayor Buckman and the entire townsfolk have gathered in t field below. They wave flags, CHEERING. What a hoot!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: It ain't so bad, you big baby! We just gonna roll ya to the bottom, is all. Then you're free to go. If you can! Lester hands Rufus a couple of hammers and a bucket of lo nails. They begin hammering them into the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I almost forgot to tell ya! We like to tickle ya a little on the way down! Malcolm's eyes bulge in rage. This simply is not happenin

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Roll out the barrel! Rufus gives the barrel a good kick and it rolls down the slide. Each revolution is pure agony for Malcolm as the nails tear into his body, ripping him apart. Upon reachin the edge, the barrel flips into the air, then crash lands on the bulls-eye below. Mayor Buckman rushes over and kneels besides Malcolm, who lies impaled on the splintered wood. His chest heaves his final, strangling breaths. Buckman jerks off his gag.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Give us that death rattle, boy! You can do it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence as Malcolm coughs, chokes, then spits a chunky mouthful of his own gore directly onto Buckman's confederate flag eye patch, quickly erasing his smile.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Kiss... my... black... ass! With that, Malcolm expires. The crowd CHEERS. Atop the tower, the Buckman Boys share a joyful embrace as Lester removes his "wig".

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Damn, Lester. You sure is sexy. Below, Buckman wipes his face with his handkerchief. Deeply perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Next time, the gag stays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door cracks ajar. Cory and Joey peek through. Seeing the place is deserted, the two enter... BONG!! A metal pail falls from above, heading towards Joe Cory quickly pulls her aside, avoiding damage.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Remind me to thank you later.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (forcing a smile) At the beach house.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. On the beach... The two tiptoe over to an antique telephone on the wall. Cory stands guard while Joey dials.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (whisper) Hello.... Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: (voice-over) This is the Operator. May I have the party you're trying to reach? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (whisper) Please connect me with the police! This is an emergency!

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: (voice-over) Now if ya spend your time chattin' on the phone, y'all gonna be late for the barbecue! Stunned, Joey slowly puts down the phone. Her expression says everything to Cory. He gets it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Anderson usually hides his cell under the mattress. Maybe they didn't find it yet. I'll go. You wait here. Keep a lookout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silo window opens. Anderson peeks through. Down below Malcolm's motorcycle can be seen, parked in one of the stalls. The only way down, however, is a twenty foot drop Contemplating his options, he leaps, landing on the haystack. It cushions his fall, but an inch to the right, and he would have been impaled on a rusty pitchfork...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory walks through the empty hall, then up the staircase, step by measured step, careful not to make a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey stands alone. Nervous. Pacing. She begins to scan th cupboards. Pie pans, rolling pin, wooden bowls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson creeps through the barn, footsteps crunching the bone-dry hay. Cautious, he pauses. The crunching continue Could someone be watching? Nah... He forges forward, passing a stockpile covered by a soiled tarp. Curious, he lifts the edge. Gasps at the familiar objects heaped befo him: His school books. The beer cooler. The boogie board. And Nelson's guitar. Broken. Bloodied. Cursing, he heads the stall housing Malcolm's bike.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey continues to take inventory, spotting a row of mason jars on the pantry shelf. She gasps! Pickled eyeballs... Pickled fingers... Pickled tongues... All human! And all with a year scrawled on the Jlabel- Festival 1875... Festival 1964... Joey is about to scream when a hand thrusts out of the darkness and covers her mouth! The unseen ATTACKER lifts her and skirts out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson hops on Malcolm's motorcycle, handkerchief wrapp round his bloodied hand. Ready to roll. Except... No keys Then, a voice from the shadows...

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: Ding dang doodle. I do believe you were tryin' to steal that colored boy's bike! Hucklebilly stands guard at the door, dangling Malcolm's keys like a carrot. Anderson approaches the boy. Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I wasn't stealing, buddy. Just borrowing. But what are you doing with the keys to that bad boy?

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: Well, truth be told, I reckoned to take a little ride myself. But Granny done say I can't on account I gotta guard the barn all day... Dumb old ugly bitch.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I hear you, bro. Hucklebilly slumps down on a bail of hay, twirling the ke Anderson sits beside him. Notes his leather wristband.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Whoa, that's a cool ass wristband you got there.

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Reverend Jonas done give me that for not tellin'.  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door open. Cory enters. Gently closes the door behind him. He turns to see a FIGURE emerging from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Is that you, Kat??

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: Nope, just little old Peaches. An ethereal vision, Peaches appears to glide across the floor as she slowly unties her tank top. Scared shitless, Cory is genuinely torn between caution and erection.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Ummmm, Joey's downstairs. She's kinda waitin' for me... Peaches locks the door, all buckteeth and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: You Northern boys may be used to uptight ladies like her... She eases Cory onto the bed then gets down on her knees.

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: .»..but one country fuck will make all them city girlies seem like nuthin' but a hole in your mattress. Cory is hesitant. Peaches begins covering her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You taking out your retainer, baby?

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: Nope. Putting something in my momma made for naughty boys just like you. Cory gets all excited. Peaches looks up and smiles---- She now wears a metal mouth piece with razor sharp edges!

dialogues.speaker: PEACHES
dialogues.text: Momma calls this my Penis Fly Trap! Before Cory can protest, Peaches puts her head between hi legs and chomps... down... HARD! He opens his mouth to scream, but nothing comes out, as a geyser of blood showe him red with repeated spurts. Holding tight to his crotch Cory slides to the floor while Peaches licks her lips cle  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits beside Hucklebilly, WHISTLING along with th as he SINGS an old rockabilly tune. Pure torture, for Hucklebilly continues to dangle the keys. The keys to fre Finally, Anderson hops to his feet, snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I know what! How about you and I go for a ride? We'll find my buddies. Play "Kill the Kitty"

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: You mean it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Sure. Just toss me the keys and you and I'll hit the road.

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: Shoot, if I go for a ride with ya, how in heck I gonna guard the barn?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I won't tell Granny if you won't. Whaddya' say? He extends his hand. Hucklebilly smiles, forks over the k

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: I say sheep doggie! Anderson jumps to the barn doors and opens them wide. Hester and Glendora stand there with guns, blocking the w

dialogues.speaker: HESTER
dialogues.text: Ring the dinner bell.

dialogues.speaker: GLENDORA
dialogues.text: It's killing time. He turns. Hucklebilly stands there grinning like the Devi aiming his slingshot...

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: You really don't think I'm that much of a moron, do ya? KAPOW! Anderson takes a rock in the head. He falls to the dirt, spilling blood, losing consciousness as everything

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world comes into view as Anderson slowly regains consciousness. It is night now, a full moon, and to his horror, Anderson discovers he is strapped down to a large picnic table, gagged. Flaming torches light the area, casting hellish shadows. The whole town is there: Granny... Harper... Rufus... Lester (and Jezebel)... Hester... Glendora... Peaches... The Milk Maiden... Hucklebilly... They sit around the table in wild anticipation, knives an forks in hands. Mayor Buckman proudly presides at the hea watching over a gagged Joey who is bound to her chair.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Just in time for the grand finale! It all comes down to this, year after year. Don't it, Granny?

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: That it does. Too bad their friends couldn't make it.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Well, that's a matter of opinion. Buckman's smile dims as he stares into Anderson's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: You Northern folk always thinkin' you can waltz right in and bring us low. But there ain't no escapin' what y'all got comin' to you! Anderson holds Buckman's gaze, refusing to look away. The moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: So who's gonna say grace? Hucklebilly? Hucklebilly rises from his seat, eyes closed, hands folde all pious and reverent. And then...

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: To our guests from the North spread at our feet, thanks for being such tasty meat! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The crowd APPLAUDS! Bowls are passed, glasses filled. The Strolling Minstrels break into a rousing rendition of "Th South is Gonna Rise Again". It's just like the 4th of Jul Sort of... Buckman moves over to the buffet table. Hester and Glendo walk up, each holding a silver platter. The Milk Maiden a Peaches approach with another. Buckman smiles, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Bet our guests will be mighty impressed when they see what Granny Boone cooked up! Like a master chef showing off, he removes a lid to revea the lovingly prepared, barbecued heads of Cory and Nelson Their pried open mouths each hold a baked cinnamon apple.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Bet you can't eat just one! Buckman unveils the other platter containing Ricky and Ka A pineapple ring dangles from the skewer still protruding from Ricky's gaping mouth. Joey and Anderson fight back vomit as the girls place the dishes on the picnic table. Rufus and Lester bring over two more platters.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Y'all like dark meat?! Buckman lifts another cover. It's Malcolm, chopped up ami chitlins and blacked eye peas.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Now, it might come as a surprise, but me, I've always been partial to Chinese. Yep. The fourth plate contains what's left of Leah's head plus a couple of smashed body parts for garnishing. Buckm grabs some Asian fried fingertips, pops 'em in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Only problem is, an hour later, I'm still hungry! Everyone CHEERS and begins dancing around the table, clapping their hands, stomping their feet. Harper and Hucklebilly ride Malcolm's motorcycle, circling the table The hellish flames from the barbecue pit seem to move to the music as the Minstrels play faster and faster. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey shuts her eyes against the madness, nearly hysterica from this insane, surrealistic nightmare. Finally, Harper hops off the bike and leaps onto the picn table, brandishing one of his spiked gapping shoes. Anderson braces as he edges closer.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: We was gonna' go easy on you, boy. Being as you was a fellow reb. Once, at least. The razor sharp points are inches away from Anderson's straining neck...

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: But then little missy over here done went and turned you. Buckman leans in. Wipes Anderson's brow with his silk.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Being a Southern gentleman, I just might give you a second chance. All you gotta do is... gut the bitch. Buckman points to Joey. Her eyes widen in fear as Granny holds out her rusty meat cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: GRANNY BOONE
dialogues.text: Why, it's just like gutting a possum, honey. Anderson studies Joey, the cleaver, the spikes at his nec Contemplating his options, he closes his eyes and nods- affirmatively! Buckman grins and cuts his bindings.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Welcome back, son, to the glory and honor! Anderson rises, takes the cleaver and walks over to Joey. Tears flowing, she braces as he slowly lifts the blade above her trembling head.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Glory and honor... Anderson swings the blade down...

dialogues.speaker: WHOMP
dialogues.text: ...cutting the ropes that bind Joey! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: You fucking maniacs wouldn't know glory and honor if it bit you flat on your Southern ass! Anderson wings the blade at Buckman, but Rufus knocks him down, taking the cleaver straight in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Stop that Yankee traitor! Hester and Glendora rush Anderson from behind, receiving mouth full of elbow as he coldcocks them both! The two to knocking over a cast iron pot loaded with cooking oil. WHOOSH! The fire pit ignites. A wall of flame spreads, separating Anderson and Joey from the townsfolk.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: (removing her gag) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: I'll kill those fucking bumpkins if they even try and touch me again!

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I guess that means yes. Anderson looks around. Points. Just yards away, Malcolm's motorcycle lies on its side. Escape! They head over. Peaches leaps over the flames, taking Joe down, all set to vampire her ass with her metal mouth gea Anderson moves in to assist, but Harper jumps in his way. His wields a spiked horseshoe, swinging at Anderson with wild sweeps, slashing, cutting... On the other side of the flames, Lester helps Buckman to his feet as Rufus extracts the cleaver like it was nothin

dialogues.speaker: RUFUS
dialogues.text: Please don't beat me, Daddy! Buckman grimaces, brushes his sons aside, then stands ato a table to observe the scrapple. The crowd follows suit more interested in watching the ladies bout than ducking the encroaching flames.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: That city girl's got more ballsack then you two flapjacks combined! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joey has become a wild animal, beating mercilessly on Peaches. Hucklebilly watches from the crowd, intrigued. I that a tit he sees? Wanting to feel useful, he aims his slingshot at Joey and opens fire... BAM!... hitting Grann Boone square in the chest! She hits the dirt. The crowd CHEERS, morons that they are. Meanwhile... Harper swings at Anderson. Slices his chest, his stomach. Anderson ducks, rolls to the ground, kicks Harper in the Harper drops the spiked horseshoe, which Anderson retriev Back to the catfight... Joey is about to deliver the final blow to Peaches when t Milk Maiden jumps in with her infamous jug. She hurls it. Joey flips out of the way. The container whacks Peaches i the cranium, cracking open and bathing her with acid! Back to the cockfight... Harper charges Anderson, who lies on the ground. Anderson swings forth with the spiked shoe, impaling Harper in the jugular. Blood spurts forth from the wound. WHOOSH! Buckman empties a bucket of water onto the flames quenching the fire. All eyes turn.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Y'all stand back. They're mine now. He moves forward, removing a long, gleaming sword. Hushed reverence grips the crowd as their Mayor licks his lips.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR BUCKMAN
dialogues.text: Shock and awe, folks. Shock and awe... Buckman lunges at Joey and Anderson, swinging his blade wide and madly. Joey rolls to the ground, banging her hea She lies there, stunned, as Anderson hops on the table. Buckman slashes, cutting the table's front legs in half. The table and Anderson come crashing down, as do the silver platters and severed heads, which spill all over h Defiant, Buckman lifts his sword and readies for the killing blow. But as he brings the blade down, Anderson grabs the nearest food scrap to block. THUNK!!! The blade connects... cutting into the back of Cory's severed head! Face to "face" with his old friend, Anderson freaks, tossing "it", and the blade, aside. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Filled with renewed vigor, Anderson jumps up and violentl hammers Buckman again and again, with a cut to the left a a cut to the right.

dialogues.speaker: POW
dialogues.text: Shaking it off, Joey moves to Anderson's side and joins in the drubbing.

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: The two pummel Buckman, relentless in their rage. Joey kicks him to his knees. Anderson wallops him in the face. ...knocking off Buckman's confederate flag eye patch, unmasking a web of flesh which bisects a gaping cavity Buckman roars, possessed, pathetically searching the grou for his fallen eye covering. Anderson grabs Joey.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: You with me?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: All the way. The two rush to the motorcycle, hop on. Anderson guns the engine and they take off, circling the field, looking for an out. But everywhere they turn, they are surrounded by maniacs. Leering. Venomous. Fucking frightening as hell. Buckman rushes forward, eye patch in hand. Anderson heads straight towards him, gunning the engine. Buckman steadies himself, smirks at Anderson, savoring their twisted game of "chicken"... that is, until he himself chickens out, ultimately stepping aside. Like Steve McQueen, Anderson hits the fallen picnic table It serves as a ramp as the bike vaults its way up and ove the townsfolk, away from Pleasant Valley and everyone in Buckman rushes forward, impotent as Anderson and Joey mak their getaway. Flanked by his bloody, wounded flock (Harper, Granny, Rufus, Lester... hell, all the maniacs), Buckman grinds his teeth, huffing, puffing. A man insane. The camera slowly MOVES IN on his vacant eye socket as a WALL OF FIRE covers the frame and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF FREIDMAN lounges at his desk, reading "Famous Monsters" magazine. At his feet, his loyal hound dog, ELVIS, gnaws on a bone. Another busy night at the office. BAM! The door bolts open. Anderson and Joey rush in, bloodied and crazed. Sheriff Freidman goes for his gun.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: No, no, no! Don't shoot!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: What the Hell is your problem, boy, chargin' in at this hour?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: You gotta help us!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: They killed our friends! They murdered them. And then they... They ate them! They fucking barbecued our friends!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: What in God's name you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: I know it sounds crazy, but it's true! What she says is true! The folks in Pleasant Valley. They're insane! Murderers! Behind Anderson, in the jail cell, CONNIE MASON, a beautiful, inexplicably well-groomed inmate, grips the ba of the cell. She has a glazed look in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I told you, Sheriff! Those people are... maniacs! Freidman glares at Miss Mason. She hushes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: They put this sign on the road, fooled us into coming to their town... Told us we were gonna be guests for some special Festival...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: We were just on a trip... Just travelling south... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: And then they started killing us one by one...

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: Pleasant Valley, you say?

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You know Pleasant Valley, right?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah... I know it, all right. The Sheriff takes a deep breath. Ponders his intruders Ponders Miss Mason. Decided, he puts his gun away.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: I think you, me and Elvis need to take a little ride. Anderson and Joey sigh relief. Connie stares forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Feels like I've been here for forty years...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HIGHWAY ROAD
dialogues.text: Anderson and Joey ride ahead of the Sheriff, who follows diligently in his squad car, hound dog by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The infamous hand painted "Detour" sign lies flat at an angle atop a pile of sawed-off branches. Seeing this, the motorcycle turns off the highway and onto the dirt road. The squad car trails behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorcycle drives along the dirt road, passing beneat the "Pleasant Valley. Population 2001" welcome sign befor coming to a halt. Anderson and Joey dismount as the squad car pulls up behind. The Sheriff gets out, flips on the spotlight and aims it at the clearing...  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson and Joey now see that they are standing dead center in the middle of a timeworn burial ground!!!! Rows of graves sprawl before them, graves carved with nam frighteningly familiar: Virginia Boone.. Harper Alexander Hester and Glendora.. Rufus, Lester (and Jez, of course). Anderson and Joey circle round in shock, trying to make sense of it all. Sheriff Freidman stares them down.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: I ought to lock you both up for wastin' my precious time! This is your Pleasant Valley! Ain't nothing but a graveyard been here the last hundred fifty years. If I hada dollar for every drunken college kid come hollerin' about flesh eatin' ghouls, me and Elvis coulda retired in comfort years ago. Anderson and Joey back away from Freidman. This can't be happening.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: No! There was a town here! People... We saw them!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: Missy, I'm just gonna assume you've been smokin' that reefer and let it go at that!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: No way, man! You're full of shit! Sheriff Freidman takes out his handcuffs. Anderson steps forward in defense.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: All right! Stop! We're sorry! It was... a joke. A prank... The Sheriff puts away the cuffs. Smirks.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure the poor souls of these fine people who died at the hands of you Northern heathens ain't so partial to your joke! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sheriff Freidman points a marble statue. None other than the chiseled likeness of Mayor George W. Buckman himself. Buckman looms tall and proud, standing guard over a tarnished plaque, circa 1862, imbedded in the earth below

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: What? Like a teacher proving his history lesson, Freidman shine his flashlight on the plaque's inscription.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF FREIDMAN
dialogues.text: It's called respect, son. Stunned, Anderson and Joey walk over to the plaque. Slowl he begins to read aloud.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: "To the 2001 innocent confederate citizens of Pleasant Valley laid to waste on this very spot by renegade Yanks during The War Between the States, this plaque is hereby devoted as a pledge of blood justice. An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, never will they rest in peace till one for one they are avenged..."

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: It's dated March 22nd. That's... today. The sound of SCREECHING TIRES jolts them to attention. Th turn to see the Sheriff's car pulling away, the DAWNING S now beginning to peek through the trees. Alone, Anderson and Joey survey the desolate landscape. 2001 graves.......

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Could we really have just imagined it all? Could it possibly be some kind of joke? Anderson points to the gash in his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: This is real. And it's no joke. That inbred Sheriff is probably one of them. We gotta do something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Maybe if we ride further north... What if we went to the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Forget the FBI. I say we get the fucking Marines and invade the South all over again. The WIND blows through the cemetery, rustling the leaves an old oak tree. The effect is that of a ghostly whisper. Or is it laughter? Joey wraps her arms around Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: You're on. She seals the pact with a kiss, continuing to hold on to Anderson for a moment of comfort. But the moment's soon over when Anderson pulls away and, with forceful venom, spits directly onto Buckman's marbled face. The final desecration...

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Pleasant Valley. With that, Anderson takes Joey's hand and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorcycle drives past the roadside sign ("Pleasant Valley. Population 2001") coursing away from the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spittle drips down the stone face of Mayor Buckman, which now appears to be smiling a malevolent grin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further up ahead... A FIGURE can be seen standing in the center of the road. Anderson slows the bike down and cautiously inches forwar Once closer, he and Joey can see that the figure is Hucklebilly, waving his arms and hootin' and hollerin'. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Oh no, not again...

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Fuck that little shit. We'll drive around him. Anderson floors the engine and speeds right past Hucklebilly, knocking him flat on his ass. The boy behind them, he and Joey turn around to take one last glimpse at Pleasant Valley. They can't help but laug with relief. Now turning to face the course ahead, they detect a line rusty BARBED WIRE extended across the dirt road between t telephone poles. It's too late to stop... Or scream. The motorcycle glides under the sharpened cord, which cut through the necks of both Anderson and Joey. Their decapitated heads fly from their bodies, which continue t ride the two-wheeler before it comes to a crashing halt a EXPLODES . The liberated heads emerge from the FLAMES, bouncing alon the path like bloody basketballs. With great finesse, Hucklebilly runs and scoops them up. Cheshire grin crosses his face from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: HUCKLEBILLY
dialogues.text: Damn Yankees! A severed head in each hand, the boy walks off into the southern sunrise, whistling Dixie...
